prompt: Facts: Marriage between Reshmi Gupta (Complainant) and Sandeep Gupta solemnized on 10.12.2005.; Preeti Gupta (Appellant No. 1) is the married sister of Sandeep Gupta (husband of the complainant).; Pradeep Kumar Gupta (Appellant No. 2) is the husband of Preeti Gupta.; Appellants reside in Navasari, Gujarat, separate from the complainant and her husband who resided in Ranchi, Jharkhand.; Complaint (Complaint Case No. 419 of 2007) filed by Reshmi Gupta before the Chief Judicial Magistrate, Ranchi, on 18.07.2007.; Allegations in the complaint: Demand for dowry (Rs. 5 Lakhs), torture, and harassment against the husband (Sandeep Gupta), father-in-law, mother-in-law, sister-in-law (Preeti Gupta - Appellant 1), and sister-in-law's husband (Pradeep Kumar Gupta - Appellant 2).; Specific allegation against Appellants: They visited Ranchi around Holi festival (March 2007), stayed for some time, demanded dowry, and assaulted the complainant.; Based on the complaint, FIR (Dowry P.S. Case No. 23 of 2007) was registered under Sections 498A, 406 IPC and Sections 3/4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961.; Police investigated and submitted a chargesheet against all five accused, including the appellants.; The learned Chief Judicial Magistrate, Ranchi took cognizance of the offences against all accused, including the appellants, on 07.11.2007.; Appellants filed a petition under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) before the High Court of Jharkhand at Ranchi for quashing the criminal proceedings against them.; The High Court dismissed the appellants' petition by its order dated 08.01.2009.; Appellants filed an appeal before the Supreme Court challenging the High Court's order.; Supreme Court noted the 'phenomenal increase in matrimonial disputes' and the 'tendency' to involve all relations of the husband, however distant.; Supreme Court observed the need for 'careful scrutiny of the complaint' by magistrates before issuing process, especially against relatives residing elsewhere. | IPC: Section 498A (Cruelty by husband or relatives of husband), Section 406 (Punishment for criminal breach of trust), Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention) - Implicitly, due to multiple accused., Section 3/4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961 (Penalty for taking/giving dowry; Penalty for demanding dowry)
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "The complaint filed by Reshmi Gupta discloses prima facie offences under Sections 498A, 406 IPC and Sections 3/4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act against all accused, including the appellants.", "precedents": ["State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal (1992) Supp (1) SCC 335: (While setting guidelines for quashing, it implies that if allegations prima facie constitute an offence and don't fall under the exceptions, investigation should proceed).", "R. P. Kapur v. State of Punjab (AIR 1960 SC 866): (Outlined grounds for quashing, suggesting that in their absence, proceedings should continue if a prima facie case exists).", "Didigam Bikshapathi v. State of A.P. (2008) 2 SCC 411: (High Court should be circumspect and reluctant to interfere with the proceedings at the threshold; quashing powers to be used sparingly)."]}, {"argument": "The veracity of the allegations is a matter of trial, and the High Court rightly refused to quash the proceedings at the initial stage under Section 482 CrPC.", "precedents": ["State of Bihar v. P.P. Sharma (1992 Supp (1) SCC 222): (Inherent power under 482 CrPC should not be used to stifle a legitimate prosecution; High Court should not act like an investigating agency).", "Zandu Pharmaceutical Works Ltd. v. Mohd. Sharaful Haque (2005) 1 SCC 122): (Parameters for quashing are strict; High Court cannot evaluate evidence at the Section 482 stage).", "Central Bureau of Investigation v. K.M. Sharan (2008) 4 SCC 471: (Power of quashing should be exercised sparingly and with circumspection, in the rarest of rare cases)."]}], "defense": [{"argument": "The implication of the appellants, who are distant relatives residing in a different state (Gujarat), is based on vague, omnibus, and general allegations, constituting a gross misuse of Section 498A IPC and an abuse of the process of law.", "precedents": ["G.V. Rao v. L.H.V. Prasad (2000) 3 SCC 693: (Courts should be careful in proceeding against distant relatives; specific allegations are necessary).", "Kans Raj v. State of Punjab (2000) 5 SCC 207: (Tendency to involve all family members needs to be curbed; specific roles must be attributed).", "Neelu Chopra v. Bharti (2009) 10 SCC 184: (Merely being related to the husband is not sufficient; specific allegations of active involvement in cruelty are required)."]}, {"argument": "The allegations against the appellants lack specificity regarding time, place, nature of the act, and individual roles, making it impossible for them to mount a proper defense and indicating the complaint is likely filed with ulterior motives.", "precedents": ["State of Karnataka v. L. Muniswamy (1977) 2 SCC 699: (Court can quash if allegations, even if taken at face value, do not constitute the offence alleged).", "Geeta Mehrotra v. State of U.P. (2012) 10 SCC 741: (Casual implication of relatives without specific allegations cannot be sustained; leads to abuse of process).", "Tabrez Khan @ Guddu v. State of U.P. (2019) SCC OnLine All 3010 (Allahabad HC - illustrative, not SC): (Reinforces need for specific allegations against each accused in 498A cases for summoning/framing charges)."]}, {"argument": "Continuing the criminal proceedings against the appellants in Ranchi would cause undue hardship and harassment, amounting to an abuse of legal process, justifying intervention under Section 482 CrPC.", "precedents": ["State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal (1992) Supp (1) SCC 335: (Category 7: Malicious prosecution instituted with an ulterior motive for wreaking vengeance).", "Inder Mohan Goswami v. State of Uttaranchal (2007) 12 SCC 1: (Inherent power is meant to prevent abuse of process and secure ends of justice).", "Anand Kumar Mohatta v. State (Govt. of NCT of Delhi) (2019) 11 SCC 706: (If complaint is primarily civil in nature or abuse of process, High Court should quash)."]}]}
